text: <@U0KPFAZNF> I've increased the timeout for unit-tests (outside Vagrant) to 40min. Unfortunately I get a similar error (when running `make dist-clean all`, during the unit tests): <https://gist.github.com/fabrice102/9d4b2167a0481dd653ef91ab1cce7073>

I've also tried the simple chaincode example (<https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-37>) after increasing startuptimeout in peer/core.yaml to 120000ms = 20 min). But deploy still times out: <https://gist.github.com/fabrice102/3269757b486452775682f05c4210d6c0>

text: so you are running this natively on OSX or within vagrant?
The two github gist are natively
ok, how much ram?
8 Gb
hmm
i would think that would be enough, though the smallest mac I have is 16G
actually, thats not true, I have an Air with 4G
i could try it there
Thanks.
can you run again with Activity Monitor open and watch the memory usage?
thats the only thing I can think of ATM without digging in deeper
(swapping to death)
the unit-tests or the deployments?
either one
im just curious if its going into memory pressure
memory used 6.91Gb
docker uses 1.6 Gb
now the deployment really started: 2017-01-12 11:22:58.659 EST [chaincode] launchAndWaitForRegister -> DEBU 0df start container: mycc:0/**TEST_CHAINID**(networkid:dev,peerid:jdoe)
total memory usage stays below 7Gb, and docker memory usage seems to stay around 1.6Gb.
hmm, its very strange
let me find that air
Thanks. I'm trying after disabling as many processes as I can, including the antivirus.
ghaskins you _could_ set up an OSX VM on OSX (you have an OS license to do that) to get down to 8 gigs
although I don't recommend it I've run Fabric in vagrant on a Windows machine with 8GB
sometimes the pointer freezes so it's definitely not a desirable work environment but it's been useful to be able to do it at times :slightly_smiling_face:
<@U0UHG4VP1> good point, I do have one
Parallels offers a 15 day trial, as well
I have a fusion license, it lets you create OSX guests
<@U3MB5BH42> how many cores in your setup?
I think 2*1.3GHz
But activity monitor does not show much cpu usage actually
ok, creating a VM now with 8G and 2x cores (though they are 3Ghz)
nor ram usage
yeah, probably not the issue
just not sure
I looked at docker logs
If I understand correctly, it seems that the chaincode just failed
but the peer did not detect that and waits until timeout

text: <@U3MB5BH42> I have a "make unit-test" just spinning up on a native Air with 4G now, and an 8GB OSX VM building
once the 8G instance comes up, will take a bit to get brew/go/docker installed, etc, but ill spin that up too
this conversation has inspired me to order more ram for my iMac
Thanks.
<@U0UHG4VP1>: ha, i _just_ did that
I went from 16G -> 48G on this macpro
best $277 bucks ive spent on computers in a while
I'm jealous. Crucial was out of 16 gig dimms so I'm going from 8 to 32 gigs
looks for somewhere to park 2 4 gig sticks
for some reason, OWC said this 4-core 2009 MP can only take 3 16G sticks
so I only ordered the 48G kit, otherwise i would have gone 64G
Theoretically, is there any reason why `make dist-clean` followed by `make docker` can fail?
<@U0XQ35CDD> are you seeing a failure?
if so, post the log?
I do, but upon further inspection it seems it's related to Gari's observation about some Unix applications not playing nicely on macOS.

```Step 3 : ADD payload/goshim.tar.bz2 $GOPATH/src/
Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file):
make: *** [build/image/ccenv/.dummy-x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-48942d73] Error 1```
So, I'll get on to fix that.
search stackoverflow for that answer
i posted it there
<http://stackoverflow.com/questions/41465720/error-building-peer-bzip2-data-invalid-in-goshim-tar-bz2>

text: Yup, on it now. Thank you.
(Update: Worked like a charm.)
<@U3MB5BH42> update: mba build is still running the chaincode test now
its working pretty hard, but still cranking without error
I think I hit a dead-end on the 8G VM front
I enabled the vmware-fusion VT-x/EPT extension to the guest, but the xhyve hypervisor is not happy and thus I cannot run docker-for-mac in this guest

on my Mac, the test after 
```unit-tests_1  | ok  	<http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core>	0.080s	coverage: 18.8% of statements```
times out. Does this corresponds to the chaincode test?
yep
thats whats cranking for me right now
just finished (the chaincode test)
overall tests still running
machines fan is cranking full speed, and the system is pretty sluggish with lots of beachball activity if I try to do anything
but it does seem to be progressing
AM has classified memory-pressure as green, though
which commit are you using?
I need to go to lunch. But I'll try with this commit afterwards.
<@U0KPFAZNF|ghaskins> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ghaskins/F3REKPA4E/screen_shot_2017-01-12_at_1.04.55_pm.png|Screen Shot 2017-01-12 at 1.04.55 PM.png>
<@U0KPFAZNF> I have macOS Sierra 10.12.2.
i cant imagine that would matter here
I'm trying with the same commit as yours
And I'm also trying on an Ubuntu VM.
For some reason make dist-clean all seems slightly faster in the VM (VirtualBox).
mine ended up failing, but it seems more like a legit test failure than the same timeout
FAIL	<http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/orderer/sbft/main|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/orderer/sbft/main>	80.118s
or at least, a different one
I've never seen this error
I really don't understand: on both the VM (VirtualBox Ubuntu 16.04) and my Mac, unit-tests time out
using the commit you've used
in the logs, I see many errors of the form
processStream -> ERRO 37d Error handling chaincode support stream: stream error: code = 1 desc = "context canceled"
[inproccontroller] func2 -> ERRO 389 chaincode ended with err: Received nil message, ending chaincode support stream
For the VM, it's a fresh install with the latest go version and the latest Docker version.
<@U3MB5BH42> I actually get similar error messages running the unit-tests
so, I wouldn't sweat it
this is why it's a work in progress...
I don't know what you're trying to achieve but unless you have a specific reason to want to use v1.0 (master) you're better off using v0.6 for now
Unfortunately, I really need v1.0, because I need multiple endorsers and system chaincodes. But I guess I can wait a week or two for it to be more stable.
What I don't really understand is how it can fail inside a Ubuntu VM.
My colleagues made it work on a fresh Ubuntu 16.04 install.

My wild guess would be that the issue is that the chaincode is trying to contact the endorser before the endorser is listening to the socket, due to some weird timing issue. And that it fails because of that. The endorser does not realize that and just wait until the test times out.

Actually on the Youtube video <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7PcpkIoGAc> (7:23), the peer does not manage to talk to the orderer via GRPC and that makes the demo fails. And we get similar error messages in the unit test logs, although the issue seems to be between the peer/endorser and the chaincode.
